written exercises. Intended to prepare students to read, understand, and
discuss modern Italian.

name: Internship Community Hth
description:
The student, through fieldwork in a community health agency, learns to apply
theory and concepts learned in the classroom.
prereq: Consent of Instructor. Upper division and graduate students.

name: Internship Pub Aff
description:
Supervised internship and study in political, governmental, or related
organizations.
prereq:
Enrollment dependent on availability of intern positions with highest priority
assigned to students with Political Science Public Service major; upper
division standing.

name: ICA Sports Program
description:
Classes offered in all UC Davis intercollegiate athletic sports and are
restricted to student-athletes who are members.

name: Special Study
description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

name: Intro to NA Lit
description:
Intensive focus on analysis of Native American literary texts, with frequent
writing assignments to develop critical thinking and composition skills.

name: Physical Geology Lab
description:
Introduction to classification and recognition of minerals and rocks and to
interpretation of topographic and geologic maps and aerial photographs.

name: Food Analysis
description:
Theory and application of physical and chemical methods for determining the
constituents of foods. Modern separation and instrumental analysis techniques
are stressed.

name: Intro to Islam
description:
Introduction to topics central to the Islamic tradition. Muhammad, the Qur'an,
Islamic law, theology, philosophy, cosmology, worship, and mysticism. Race and
gender in Islam, Islamic revival, and varying experiences of Islam in
different historical and cultural settings.

name: History Of Life Lab
description:
Exercises in understanding fossils as the clues to interpreting ancient life,
including their functional morphology, paleoecology, and evolution.
prereq: GEL 003 { can be concurrent }; GEL 003 required concurrently.

name: Nat Amer Ethno-Hist
description: Study of Native American ethno-history in North America after 1890.
prereq: Upper division standing or consent of instructor.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Seminar
description:
In-depth examination of topics in sociology. Emphasis on student research and
writing.

name: Early Music Ensemble
description:
Rehearsal and performance of Medieval, Renaissance, and Baroque music for
vocal ensemble and historical instruments.
prereq: Consent of Instructor. Admission by audition.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Research Methods Seminar
description:
Intensive reading, discussion, research, and writing in selected topics in
Research Methods such as research design, statistics, game theory, etc.
prereq: Upper division Political Science majors or consent of instructor.

name: Physiology Foundations
description:
Focuses on the structure, function, and interactions of animal organ systems
in homeostasis and reproduction, and the response to perturbations of
homeostasis; neural and endocrine signaling; skeletal muscle and movement;
cardiovascular and respiratory systems; renal, digestive, immune, and
reproductive physiology.
prereq: NPB 110A C- or better; PHY 007A; PHY 007B and PHY 007C recommended.

name: Electronics
description:
Continuation of PHY 116A. Introduction to the use of digital electronics and
microcomputers in experimental physics. Nonlinear electronics, integrated
circuits, analog-to-digital and digital-to-analog converters, transducers,
actuators.
prereq: PHY 009C or PHY 009HD; or Consent of Instructor.

name: Physical Activities
description:
Physical Education Activities classes offered in the following areas:
aquatics, personal fitness, martial arts, individual sports, and team sports.
These academic classes are instructional rather than recreational and are
intended to improve activity specific skills and knowledge.

name: Restoration Practicum
description:
Hands-on field exposure to various aspects of ecological restoration
throughout the seasonal restoration cycle with real-world practitioners.
Emphasis on grassland/rangeland, riparian, and oak woodland communities.

name: Coaching Effectiveness
description:
Synthesis and application of basic components of sport psychology, sport
pedagogy, and sport physiology and basic management and administration of
athletics in public high schools.
prereq: Upper division standing; 3 units of PHE 001 and PHE 006 combined.

name: US Since 1945
Global Social Change
description:
Introduction to change and diversity in world history, including the United
States. Examines population and family, technological change and economic
development, power and status, culture and identity.

name: History Of The U S
description:
The experience of the American people from the Civil War to the end of the
Cold War.

name: Calculus
description:
Continuation of MAT 021A. Definition of definite integral, fundamental theorem
of calculus, techniques of integration. Application to area, volume, arc
length, average of a function, improper integral, surface of revolution. May
be taught abroad.
prereq: (MAT 021A C- or better or MAT 021AH C- or better) or MAT 017A B or better

name: Classical Physics
description: Electricity and magnetism including circuits and Maxwell's equations.
prereq: PHY 009B; MAT 021D; MAT 022A { can be concurrent }

name: Calculus for BioSci
description:
Introduction to differential calculus via applications in biology and
medicine. Limits, derivatives of polynomials, trigonometric, and exponential
functions, graphing, applications of the derivative to biology and medicine.
prereq:
Two years of high school algebra, plane geometry, plane trigonometry, and
analytical geometry, and satisfying the Mathematics Placement Requirement.

name: Elementary Japanese
description: Continuation of training in basic Japanese spoken and written skills.
prereq: JPN 001 C- or better; Or the equivalent language proficiency.

name: General Physics
description: Continuation of PHY 007A.

name: Applied Stat for Bio Sci
description:
Descriptive statistics, probability, sampling distributions, estimation,
hypothesis testing, contingency tables, ANOVA, regression; implementation of
statistical methods using computer package.

name: Colonialism
description:
History of the modern world, focusing on struggles between Europeans and
colonized peoples; the global formation of capitalism; the creation of nation-
states; and the constitution of bourgeois bodies and racial selves in modern
societies.

name: The Bible & Film
description:
Examination of the uses of the Judeo-Christian Scriptures in film. Topics
include dramatic depictions of biblical stories, the tension between science
and religion, allegorical treatments of biblical themes, and the problems of
religious conviction.

name: Elem Hindi/Urdu II
description:
Continuation of course 1. Devanagari Script through development of all
language skills in a cultural context with emphasis on communicative
proficiency.

name: Systemic Physiology Lab
description:
Selected experiments to illustrate functional characteristics of organ systems
discussed in NPB 101.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: History People Rep China
description:
Comprehensive analysis of recent Chinese history, including land reform, the
Cultural Revolution, the post-Mao era, and the consequences of the new
economic policies of the 1980s.

name: Molecules to Individuals
description:
Major concepts in cell biology with special emphasis on connections between
cell biology and behavior. Includes: cellular metabolism, cellular sensing and
signaling, membrane structure-function, molecular switches, electrical and
chemical signaling, endocrine signaling, cell cycle and differentiation,
cytoskeleton, and integrative examples. May be taught abroad.
prereq:
(BIS 002A, BIS 002B); (CHE 002B or CHE 003A); PHY 007A and PHY 007B
recommended; BIS 002C recommended.

name: Intro Music Theory 2
description:
Continuation of MUS 003A. Development of melodic and harmonic writing skills.
Basic analysis training. Intended for the general student.

name: Feeding the World
description:
Scientific principles and dynamic interactions involved in food production,
food processing, nutrition, shelf life and marketing from differing
viewpoints. Physical, biological and social science issues influencing the
availability and safety of the food supply worldwide.

name: University Concert Band
description: Rehearsal and performance of music for band.
prereq: Consent of Instructor. Admission by audition.

name: Elem Human Physiology
description:
Introduction to physiology for non-science majors. Includes basic cell
physiology and survey of major organ systems and how they function in
homeostasis and human health.

name: Fld Std Of Elderly
description:
Apply theory and research on adult development and aging, work with older
adults in a variety of settings, and develop skills relevant to that
application. Develop a small research project.
prereq: HDE 100C or HDE 160 { can be concurrent }; and Consent of Instructor.

name: Special Study Undergrad
description: Intended for lower division students.

name: Physical Activities
description:
Physical Education Activities classes offered in the following areas:
aquatics, personal fitness, martial arts, individual sports, and team sports.
These academic classes are instructional rather than recreational and are
intended to improve activity specific skills and knowledge.

name: Classical Physics
description: Electricity and magnetism including circuits and Maxwell's equations.
prereq: PHY 009B; MAT 021D; MAT 022A { can be concurrent }

name: Foundations Pol Thought
description:
Analysis and evaluation of the seminal works of a major political philosopher
or of a major problem in political philosophy.

name: Short Calculus
description:
Differential equations; partial derivatives; double integrals; applications;
series.
prereq:
MAT 016B C- or better or MAT 017B C- or better or MAT 021B C- or better or MAT
021BH C- or better

name: East Asian Civ
description:
Surveys traditional Chinese civilization and its modern transformation.
Emphasis is on thought and religion, political and social life, art and
literature. Perspectives on contemporary China are provided.

name: Black Hist In Amer
description:
History of black people in the United States from the African background to
Reconstruction.

name: Elementary Theory
description: Continuation of MUS 006A.
prereq:
MUS 002B { can be concurrent }; MUS 016B { can be concurrent }; required
concurrently; completion of MUS 006A or demonstration of required proficiency
level on diagnostic exam.

name: Intermed Algebra
description:
Basic concepts of algebra, prepares student for college work in mathematics,
such as MAT 016A or MAT 021A. Functions, equations, graphs, logarithms, and
systems of equations. Offered only if sufficient number of students enroll.

name: Regression Analysis
description:
Simple linear regression, variable selection techniques, stepwise regression,
analysis of covariance, influence measures, computing packages.
prereq: STA 013 or STA 013Y or STA 032 or STA 100

name: Academic Literacies
description:
Composition, the essay, paragraph structure, diction, and related topics.
Frequent writing assignments.

name: Writing in Health Prof
description:
Advanced expository writing common in the health professions, emphasizing
effective communication between the writer and different audiences. Topics
relate to health, disability, and disease. Suitable for students planning
careers in professions such as medicine, dentistry, physical therapy,
optometry.
prereq:
UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL
003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C-
or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division
standing.

name: Intrmed Multiling Wrtng
description:
Reading and writing short multi-paragraph texts for academic purposes.
Suitable for students whose primary home language was not English.

name: Academic Literacies
description:
Composition, the essay, paragraph structure, diction, and related topics.
Frequent writing assignments.

name: Physical Activities
description:
Physical Education Activities classes offered in the following areas:
aquatics, personal fitness, martial arts, individual sports, and team sports.
These academic classes are instructional rather than recreational and are
intended to improve activity specific skills and knowledge.

name: Elementary Latin
description: Continuation of LAT 001.

name: Prof Act Men & Wom
description:
Fundamental skills for: (a) coaching competitive athletics; (b) classroom
teaching and coaching, and (c) classroom teaching and officiating. May be
repeated for a total of six units.

name: Genres in Prof Writing
description:
Instruction in the elements and practices of professional writing in
specialized genres. May be taught abroad.
prereq: Satisfaction of the upper division writing requirement.

name: Advanced Composition
description:
Instruction in advanced principles of expository writing. Writing tasks within
and beyond the University. Different writing modes, including narrative,
analysis, explanation, argument, critique. May be taught abroad.
prereq:
UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or COM
001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C-
or better or ENL 003 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division
standing.

name: Seminar on Altern Agric
description:
Seminar on topics related to alternative theories, practices and systems of
agriculture and the relationship of agriculture to the environment and
society. Scientific, technological, social, political and economic
perspectives.
prereq: Upper division standing or consent of instructor.

name: Molec Biol & Biochem Lab
description:
Introduction to laboratory methods and procedures employed in studying
molecular biology and biochemical processes. Designed for students who need
experience in use of molecular biology and biochemical techniques as research
and analytical tools.
prereq: BIS 102; or Consent of Instructor. Must be taken concurrently with MCB 120.

name: Int Social Research
description:
Data-analysis techniques, measurement, scaling, multivariate analysis, and
quantitative measures of association.

name: Directed Gp Study
description: Primarily for lower division students. May be taught abroad.
prereq: Consent of instructor and department chairperson.

name: Lab: Early Childhood
description:
Application of theories of learning and development to interaction with
infants, toddlers, and preschoolers at Early Childhood Laboratory. Applied
skills in communication, guidance and curriculum.
prereq:
HDE 140 { can be concurrent }; and Consent of Instructor. HDE 140 must be
taken concurrently for first 3 units of credit; students must contact the
Center for Child & Family Studies to enroll.

name: Food Properties
description:
Sensory quality, chemical and microbial safety, and nutritional properties of
foods. Effects of food processing and preparation on these properties.
Selected properties of food commodities.
prereq: FST 100A; CHE 008B; and Consent of Instructor.

name: Differential Equations
description: Solutions of elementary differential equations.
prereq: (MAT 022A C- or better or MAT 067 C- or better)

name: Investigative Journalism
description:
Instruction in the elements and practices of in-depth investigative
journalism.
prereq: Satisfaction of the upper division writing requirement.

name: College Writing-SCC157E
description: Not available.

name: Feminist Research
description:
Introduction to feminist applications and transformations of traditional
disciplinary research practices; initial training in methodologies for
feminist interdisciplinary work.

name: Phys Ecol of Wildlife
description:
Principles of physiological ecology, emphasizing vertebrates. Ecological,
evolutionary, and behavioral perspectives on physiological mechanisms used by
animals to adapt to their environment, including consideration of climate-
change and other threats to biodiversity. Tropical, temperate, and polar
ecosystems are highlighted.
prereq:
EVE 101 or ESP 100; (BIS 002A, BIS 002B, BIS 002C); Or equivalent course to
ESP 100.

name: Journalism
description:
Non-fiction for magazines and newspapers, with attention to style and
language. Emphasis on research, interviewing, market analysis, and query
letters.
prereq:
UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL
003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C-
or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division
standing.

name: Advanced Composition
description:
Instruction in advanced principles of expository writing. Writing tasks within
and beyond the University. Different writing modes, including narrative,
analysis, explanation, argument, critique. May be taught abroad.
prereq:
UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or COM
001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C-
or better or ENL 003 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division
standing.

name: Musics of the World
description:
Survey of selected art, folk, and popular music cultures from different parts
of the world. Emphasis on understanding relationship of musical style,
aesthetic principles, and performance practice to wider cultural contexts.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Calculus
description:
Continuation of MAT 021A. Definition of definite integral, fundamental theorem
of calculus, techniques of integration. Application to area, volume, arc
length, average of a function, improper integral, surface of revolution. May
be taught abroad.
prereq: (MAT 021A C- or better or MAT 021AH C- or better) or MAT 017A B or better

name: American Voices
description:
Explores the forms of American English: traditional notions of regional
dialects and increasingly important social dialects, reflecting age, class,
gender, race, ethnicity, and sexual orientation. Influence of language
attitudes on perception of dialect speakers; dialect in media, education, and
literature.
prereq: LIN 001 or LIN 001Y or ANT 004; Or upper division standing recommended.

name: Prof Act Men & Wom
description:
Fundamental skills for: (a) coaching competitive athletics; (b) classroom
teaching and coaching, and (c) classroom teaching and officiating. May be
repeated for a total of six units.

name: Nutrition Practicum
description:
Fundamental principles of planning and evaluating therapeutic diets and
patient education for pathological conditions covered in NUT 116B.
Continuation of NUT 116AL.

name: Soil Microbiology
description:
Major groups of microorganisms in soil, their interrelationships, and their
responses to environmental variables. Role of microorganisms in cycling of
nutrients. Plant-microbe relationships. Transformations of organic and
inorganic pollutants.

name: Edu & Inequality in US
description:
Functions of schooling in contemporary U.S. society. Racial, ethnic, social
class, and gender inequalities in student outcomes. Consideration of classic
and current controversies in the sociology of education and education policy.

name: Comp Math Physics
description:
Introduction to the use of computational techniques to solve the mathematical
problems that arise in advanced physics courses, complementing the analytical
approaches emphasized in PHY 104A.
prereq: PHY 104A C- or better; PHY 105AL; or Consent of Instructor.

name: Women & Gender Amer-1865
description:
History of women and gender in America through 1865, emphasizing intersections
of gender, race, class, and sexuality. Topics include interracial marriage,
slavery, witchcraft, meanings of motherhood, war, domestic labor, moral
reform, womens rights, migrations, the effects of commercialization and
industrialization.

name: Intrnatl Pol Middle East
description:
International politics of the Middle East as a microcosm of world politics.
The Middle East as a regional system. Domestic and International Politics in
the Middle East. Changing Political Structures in the Middle East. Superpower
involvement in the Middle East.

name: Intro Linguistics
description: Introduction to the study of language; its nature, diversity, and structure.

name: Discov & Concepts
description:
Nutrition as a science; historical development of nutrition concepts;
properties of nutrients and foods.

name: Advancd Multiling Wrtng
description:
Reading and writing source/research-based texts for academic purposes.
Suitable for students whose primary home language was not English.

name: Intrmed Multiling Wrtng
description:
Reading and writing short multi-paragraph texts for academic purposes.
Suitable for students whose primary home language was not English.

name: Willow Clinic
description:
Student run clinic for upper division students interested in learning about
and meeting the unique health care needs for the homeless population.
prereq: Consent of Instructor. UC Davis enrollment; upper division standing.

name: College Writing-SCC157S
description: Not available.

name: Academic Literacies
description:
Composition, the essay, paragraph structure, diction, and related topics.
Frequent writing assignments.

name: Academic Literacies
description:
Composition, the essay, paragraph structure, diction, and related topics.
Frequent writing assignments.

name: Technical Writing
description:
Communicating effectively about technology and other technical subjects to
varied audiences for varied purposes. Suitable for students entering
professions that require communicating technical information to subject matter
experts, managers, technicians, and non-specialists.
prereq:
UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL
003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C-
or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division
standing.

name: Academic Literacies
description:
Composition, the essay, paragraph structure, diction, and related topics.
Frequent writing assignments.

name: Intrmed Multiling Wrtng
description:
Reading and writing short multi-paragraph texts for academic purposes.
Suitable for students whose primary home language was not English.

name: Physical Activities
description:
Physical Education Activities classes offered in the following areas:
aquatics, personal fitness, martial arts, individual sports, and team sports.
These academic classes are instructional rather than recreational and are
intended to improve activity specific skills and knowledge.

name: American Humanities
description:
Introduction to humanities topics and methodologies; analysis of major
figures, works, and genres in American arts and literatures, with emphasis on
relationships between history, society, and culture.

name: Systemic Physiology
description:
Systemic physiology with emphasis on aspects of human physiology. Functions of
major organ systems, with the structure of those systems described as a basis
for understanding the functions.
prereq: BIS 001A or BIS 002A; CHE 002B; PHY 001B or PHY 007C strongly recommended.

name: College Writing-SCC157S
description: Not available.

name: Indust & Social Change
description:
Selected technological and social factors. Preconditions of economic
development and industrialization. Social, political, and cultural issues at
various levels of economic development. Major historical differences and major
current trends. Emphasis either on highly industrialized countries or on less
developed countries.

name: Genocide
description:
Comparative and critical study of the modern phenomenon of genocide from
religious, ethical and historical perspectives.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Linear Algebra
description:
Matrices and linear transformations, determinants, eigenvalues, eigenvectors,
diagonalization, factorization. Not open for credit to students who have
completed course 67.
prereq:
MAT 016C C- or better or MAT 017C C- or better or MAT 021C C- or better or MAT
021CH C- or better; (ENG 006 or EME 005 or MAT 022AL { can be concurrent })

name: Intro to NA Lit
description:
Intensive focus on analysis of Native American literary texts, with frequent
writing assignments to develop critical thinking and composition skills.

name: Internship
description:
Work experience on or off campus in practical application of nutrition,
supervised by a faculty member.
prereq: Consent of Instructor. One upper division course in nutrition.

name: Spanish Cultural Studies
description:
Study of specific historical tendencies in Spanish culture(s) from the Romans
to the present. Sources studied may include literature, film, art, journalism,
and performance. Approaches to material may address issues of aesthetics,
politics, identity, and globalization.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Convex Geometry
description:
Topics selected from the theory of convex bodies, convex functions, geometric
inequalities, combinatorial geometry, and integral geometry. Designed to serve
as preparation for the more rigorous upper division courses.

name: Systemic Physiology Disc
description:
Discussion and problem solving related to fundamental principles of systemic
physiology as presented in NPB 101.
prereq: NPB 101 { can be concurrent }; Consent of Instructor.

name: Real Analysis
description:
Functions, limits of functions, continuity and uniform continuity, sequences
of functions, series of real numbers, series of functions, power series.

name: University Chorus
description: Rehearsal and performance of choral music.
prereq: Consent of Instructor. Admission by audition.

name: Cyborgs & Prostheses
description:
Interface of biology and technology. Mind-controlled prosthetic limbs,
artificial organs, and implantable devices. Emphasis on basic physiological
functions and how they can be replaced by devices. Suitable for majors and
non-majors.

name: Journalism
description:
Non-fiction for magazines and newspapers, with attention to style and
language. Emphasis on research, interviewing, market analysis, and query
letters.
prereq:
UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL
003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C-
or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division
standing.

name: Academic Literacies
description:
Composition, the essay, paragraph structure, diction, and related topics.
Frequent writing assignments.

name: Electricity & Magnetism
description:
Theory of electrostatics, electromagnetism, Maxwell's equations,
electromagnetic waves.
prereq:
PHY 009B C- or better; PHY 009C C- or better; PHY 009D C- or better; MAT 021D
C- or better; MAT 022A C- or better; MAT 022B C- or better; PHY 104A; PHY
105A; Or consent of department.

name: Legal Writing
description:
Advanced principles of critical thinking, argumentation, and style, with
special emphasis on their application in the legal profession. Suitable for
students planning careers in law, business, administration, or management.
prereq:
UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL
003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C-
or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division
standing.

name: Viticultural Practices
description:
Theory, principles, and practices of pruning and grapevine propagation. Plant
materials and the certification process, weed control and weed identification,
wood diseases, and frost protection. One field trip required.

name: Writ in HumDev and Psych
description:
Advanced instruction in writing and practice in effective styles of
communication in Human Development & Psychology.
prereq:
UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL
003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C-
or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division
standing.

description:
Reading and writing source/research-based texts for academic purposes.
Suitable for students whose primary home language was not English.

Instruction in advanced principles of expository writing. Writing tasks within
and beyond the University. Different writing modes, including narrative,
analysis, explanation, argument, critique. May be taught abroad.
prereq:
UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or COM
001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C-
or better or ENL 003 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division
standing.

name: College Writing-SCC157S

and beyond the University. Different writing modes, including narrative,
analysis, explanation, argument, critique. May be taught abroad.
prereq:
UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or COM
001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C-
or better or ENL 003 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division
standing.

name: Behavioral Ecology
description:
Basic theories underlying the functional and evolutionary significance of
behavior, and the role of ecological constraints. Supporting empirical
evidence taken mainly from studies of wild vertebrates.
prereq:
EVE 101 or ESP 100 { can be concurrent }; (BIS 002A, BIS 002B, BIS 002C); Or
equivalent course.

name: Advancd Multiling Wrtng
description:
Reading and writing source/research-based texts for academic purposes.
Suitable for students whose primary home language was not English.

name: Cognitive Neuroscience
description:
Neuroscientific foundations of higher mental processes including attention,
memory, language, higher-level perceptual and motor processes, and
consciousness. Emphasis on the neural mechanisms which form the substrates of
human cognition and the relationship of mind to brain.
prereq:
(PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 041; or Consent of Instructor. PSC 101, PSC 121, or
PSC 129 recommended.

name: Disease Ecology
description:
Introduction to the dynamics and control of infectious disease in wildlife,
including zoonotic diseases and those threatening endangered species. Basic
epidemiological models and application to field data. Scientists' role in
developing disease control policies.
prereq: BIS 002A; BIS 002B; BIS 002C; or equivalent. EVE 100 is recommended.

name: Writing in Health Prof
description:
Advanced expository writing common in the health professions, emphasizing
effective communication between the writer and different audiences. Topics
relate to health, disability, and disease. Suitable for students planning
careers in professions such as medicine, dentistry, physical therapy,
optometry.
prereq:
UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL
003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C-
or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division
standing.

name: Health & Med Tech
description:
Critical/historical examination of medical technologies: imaging,
pharmaceuticals, genetics, implants/devices. Exploration of mutually
constitutive relationship between health, medical technologies, social
difference (race/gender/class/sexuality).

name: Plant Biochemistry
description:
The biochemistry of important plant processes and metabolic pathways.
Discussion of methods used to understand plant processes, including use of
transgenic plants.

name: Dostoevsky (In Eng)
description:
Reading and analysis of Dostoevskys principal works such as Crime and
Punishment, The Idiot, The Brothers Karamazov, and The Diary. Study of social
and political views as reflected in Dostoevskys works.

name: History Of Chile
description:
Emphasis on the history of Chilean political economy from 1930 to the present.
Various strategies of development (modernization, Marxism, Neo-Liberalism);
the rise of mass politics; the course of foreign relations; and the richness
of Chilean literature.

name: Jazz Fundamentals
description:
Fundamentals of Jazz music theory, ear training, harmony and composition
techniques. Designed to complement participation in Jazz Combo or Jazz Band.
First of a three-course sequence.
prereq: MUS 003A C- or better; or Consent of Instructor.

name: Latin Amer Soc Rev
Mnging & Using Info Tech
description:
Develop an analytical framework to manage and monitor business systems
concerned with operational, human, and organizational interactions.
Introduction to computer hardware, systems software, and information systems.
Management of information technology and the impact of information systems on
modern management.

name: NA Art Studio
description:
Studio projects to be influenced by contemporary and traditional Native
American arts. Examples of designs and media presented in lectures will be of
indigenous origin. Introduction and familiarized with various materials and
techniques.

name: Nonparametric Statistics
description:
Sign and Wilcoxon tests, Walsh averages. Two-sample procedures. Inferences
concerning scale. Kruskal-Wallis test. Measures of association. Chi square and
Kolmogorov-Smirnov tests.
prereq: STA 013 or STA 013Y or STA 032 or STA 100

name: Ordinary Diff Equations
Rangeland Ecology
description:
Introduction to the ecological principles and processes important for an
understanding of the dynamics of range ecosystems. Emphasis on ecological and
evolutionary concepts underlying management strategies for conserving
biological diversity and environmental quality in rangelands.
prereq:
PLS 002 or BIS 002B or BIS 002C; or Consent of Instructor. Upper division
standing

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Advancd Multiling Wrtng
description:
Reading and writing source/research-based texts for academic purposes.
Suitable for students whose primary home language was not English.

name: Linear Algebra
description:
Matrices and linear transformations, determinants, eigenvalues, eigenvectors,
diagonalization, factorization. Not open for credit to students who have
completed course 67.
prereq:
MAT 016C C- or better or MAT 017C C- or better or MAT 021C C- or better or MAT
021CH C- or better; (ENG 006 or EME 005 or MAT 022AL { can be concurrent })

name: Bas Cnpt/Pol Thry
description:
Analysis of such concepts as the individual, community, liberty, equality,
justice, and natural law as developed in the works of the major political
philosophers.

name: Directed Group Study
description: Directed group study.

name: Math Statistics
description:
Sampling, methods of estimation, bias-variance decomposition, sampling
distributions, Fisher information, confidence intervals, and some elements of
hypothesis testing.
prereq: STA 131A or MAT 135A; or Consent of Instructor.

name: Directed Gp Study
description: Not available.

name: Academic Literacies
description:
Composition, the essay, paragraph structure, diction, and related topics.
Frequent writing assignments.

name: Spanish Composition II
description:
Development of advanced level writing skills, with emphasis on how to write
argumentative prose, essays, and research papers. Introduction to the analysis
of literary genres. Compositions, journals, individual and group projects.

name: Writing in Education
description:
Advanced expository writing in the contemporary American classroom. Strongly
recommended for teaching credential candidates.
prereq:
UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL
003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C-
or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division
standing.

name: Calculus for BioSci
description:
Introduction to differential calculus via applications in biology and
medicine. Limits, derivatives of polynomials, trigonometric, and exponential
functions, graphing, applications of the derivative to biology and medicine.
prereq:
Two years of high school algebra, plane geometry, plane trigonometry, and
analytical geometry, and satisfying the Mathematics Placement Requirement.

name: Global Climate Change
description:
Causes of global climate change and the biological, geophysical, and social
consequences of such change. Methods used by different scientists for
predicting future events. Complexity of global affairs. Decision making under
uncertainty.

name: Labor
description:
Labor and employment issues in the contemporary United States with some use of
historical and comparative materials. Topics include strategies pursued by
employers and employees, labor market discrimination and the role of social
policies in shaping labor markets.

name: Internship
description: Work experience on or off campus in the practical application of food science.

name: Calculus for BioSci
description:
Matrix algebra, functions of several variables, partial derivatives, systems
of differential equations, and applications to biology and medicine.

name: Applied Statistics
description:
Descriptive statistics; probability; random variables; expectation; binomial,
normal, Poisson, other univariate distributions; joint distributions; sampling
distributions, central limit theorem; properties of estimators; linear
combinations of random variables; testing and estimation; Minitab computing
package.
prereq:
(STA 013 or STA 013Y or STA 032 or STA 100); (MAT 016B or MAT 017B or MAT
021B)

name: History Of The U S
description: The experience of the American people from the Colonial Era to the Civil War.

name: Prof Act Men & Wom
description:
Fundamental skills for: (a) coaching competitive athletics; (b) classroom
teaching and coaching, and (c) classroom teaching and officiating. May be
repeated for a total of six units.

name: Gender
description:
Analysis of biological, psychological, cultural and structural conditions
underlying the status and roles of men and women in contemporary society,
drawing on a historical and comparative perspective.

name: Cognitive Development
description:
Theories, methods, evidence, and debates in the field of cognitive
development, such as nature/nurture, constraints on learning, and the role of
plasticity. Topics include attention, memory, concepts about the physical and
social world, and language.

name: Mid Childh & Adol
description:
Interplay of biological and social-cultural factors in the emotional,
cognitive and social development from middle childhood through adolescence.

name: Linear Algebra Comp Lab
description: Introduction to MATLAB and its use in linear algebra.
prereq: MAT 016C or MAT 017C or MAT 021C or MAT 021CH

name: Advancd Multiling Wrtng
description:
Reading and writing source/research-based texts for academic purposes.
Suitable for students whose primary home language was not English.

name: Principles Lit Criticism
description:
Principles of literary criticism applied to the study of fiction, drama,
poetry, and essay of major literary writers of the Hispanic world.

name: Advanced Composition
description:
Instruction in advanced principles of expository writing. Writing tasks within
and beyond the University. Different writing modes, including narrative,
analysis, explanation, argument, critique. May be taught abroad.
prereq:
UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or COM
001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C-
or better or ENL 003 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division
standing.

name: Herpetology
description:
Evolution and ecology of the worlds diverse reptiles and amphibians. Emphasis
on adaptations to environments, species interactions, management, and
conservation.
prereq: BIS 002A; BIS 002B; BIS 002C; Upper division ecology course recommended.

name: Asian Philosophy
description:
Survey of the main philosophical systems of south and east Asia: Hinduism,
Buddhism, Confucianism, and Taoism. Topics include the nature of reality,
including God, the universe and the human self, human knowledge, and the
proper conduct of human life.

name: College Writing-SCC157E
description: Not available.

name: Academic Literacies
description:
Composition, the essay, paragraph structure, diction, and related topics.
Frequent writing assignments.

name: Renaissance/Reformation
description:
Survey of European society, politics, and culture from the late 15th through
the early 17th centuries, with particular focus on the Italian and Northern
Renaissance, on the Protestant Reformation, and the Catholic Counter
Reformation.

name: Neurobiology
description:
Brains and nervous systems, neurons and neural circuits. Coordination of
movement. Development of nervous systems. Vision, hearing, and feature
extraction by the central nervous system. The cell biology of learning and
memory. Perception, cognition, and disorders of the brain.
prereq:
BIS 002A; BIS 002B; BIS 002C; PHY 009A, 009B, 009C or PHY 007A, 007B, 007C
recommended.

name: Analytical Mechanic
instructor: Manuel Calderon De La Barca Sanchez
description:
Principles and applications of Newtonian mechanics; introduction to Lagranges
and Hamiltons equations
prereq:
PHY 104A C or better; PHY 105A C or better; Or consent of department for any
of the courses.

name: Music from Latin America
description:
Examination of music from Latin America. Characteristic music (i.e., tango,
bossa nova, salsa, musica motena, musica andina) as well as its implications
in other musical genres. Taught in English or Spanish depending on instructor.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: The Family
description:
Contemporary family life in historical and cross-cultural perspective. How
different family forms arose, their significance today and prospects for
further family change. Attention to power relations within and beyond the
family and to the social implications of family transformation.

name: Neurobiology Foundations
description:
Core concepts of neurobiology including single-neuron biophysics, synapses and
transmitters, neuronal development, motor systems, central pattern generation,
neuronal circuits, intracellular signal transduction, sensory processing,
multisensory integration, autonomic nervous system, neuromodulation, learning
and memory, and higher cognition and disease.
prereq: NPB 110A C- or better; PHY 007A and PHY 007B recommended.

name: First-Year Seminar
description:
Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written
assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site
visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in
learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take
more than one in any given quarter.

name: Complex Organizations
description:
Develops a sociological approach to organizations theory. Designed to
introduce sociological concepts, address the alternative psychological and
economic models, and involve students in the practice of organizational
analysis.

name: Intrmed Multiling Wrtng
description:
Reading and writing short multi-paragraph texts for academic purposes.
Suitable for students whose primary home language was not English.

name: Internship in Writing
description:
Internships in fields where students can practice their skills. May be taught
abroad.
prereq:
UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y or ENL 003; or equivalent course; consent of
instructor.

name: Clothing Mat Sci
description:
The properties, characterization, and performance evaluation of clothing
materials and structures for specific functional applications. Principles and
methods related to wetting and transport properties, fabric hand and aesthetic
properties, clothing comfort, and material and assembly technology.

name: College Writing-SCC157S
description: Not available.

name: College Writing-SCC157S
description: Not available.

name: Academic Literacies
description:
Composition, the essay, paragraph structure, diction, and related topics.
Frequent writing assignments.

name: Combinatorics
description:
Combinatorial methods using basic graph theory, counting methods, generating
functions, and recurrence relations. Designed to serve as preparation for the
more rigorous upper division courses.

name: Wine Stability Lab
description:
Practical application of principles of equilibria and rates of physical and
chemical reactions to wine stability.
prereq: VEN 126 { can be concurrent }; and Consent of Instructor.

name: Gateway to Data Science
description:
Probability concepts; programming in R; exploratory data analysis; sampling

Appointments as a(n) director, director of photography, actor, writer,

produce and submit a short film to a film festival.

name: Global Gender & Culture
description:
Critical gender analysis of globalization as a process of interconnected
cultural, social and economic transformations inflected by gender, nation,
class and race/ethnicity. Critical self-reflection and social observation
skills.

Limits; differentiation of algebraic functions; analytic geometry;

name: Combinatorics
description:
Combinatorial methods using basic graph theory, counting methods, generating

name: Intro Music History
description:
History of music from the Romantic Period to the 19th century. Intended

description:
Workings of electoral institutions, focusing on systems used to elect
presidents and assemblies, pass laws, and generally make decisions. Examples

interpretation of results. Laboratory exercises to collect data, analyze and
interpret results, and write scientific papers.

presentation/discussion of major ideas, vocabulary expansion, and writing

inference; one-way MANOVA; discriminant analysis; principal components;
canonical correlation; factor analysis. Intensive use of computer analyses and
real data sets.
